title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Iran to the point by the narrow square opening into the soft sandstonerock, and lying low on my face I could see a lugger close in under theheugh of Boreland, where she would never have dared to go, save that thewind was off shore and steady.

title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Iran to the point by the narrow square opening into the soft sandstonerock, and lying low on my face I could see a lugger close in under theheugh of Boreland, where she would never have dared to go, save that thewind was off shore and steady.

title: The Black Douglas
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: In an hour Sholto followed them, having ridden fast and furious acrossthe long broomy braes of Boreland, and wet the fringes of hischarger's silken coverture by vaingloriously swimming the Dee at thecastle pool instead of going round by the fords.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: No little mills were set birling in the burns of Glenlochar and Boreland.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: She could not go to the Boreland or be seen on the Glebe Road, she could not examine the spot where as the spring night drew to morning Sandy Ewan had gripped his last handful of earth and weeds.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: In fact, he could easily reconstitute the scene at the Boreland to himself.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "Wha' was the man that was comin' to the Boreland.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It gied a man a fine regairdless cock to his Sunday bonnet to spend a winter aboot the Boreland.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It was in the deep heart of the night when Crob McRobb  arrived at the Boreland.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: So by the time that Sandy Ewan had reached the Boreland  of Kirkanders a plan had begun to take shape in his mind.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: "Maister Ewan ye surely ken young Maister Alexander  o' the Boreland," said the sycophant, hoping that the person named might hear.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Juist fleechin' and prayin' o'er me that I wadna leave them a' thegither! But what yin o' them a' ever had the chance to be mistress o' the Boreland  o' Kirkanders a laird's wife sittin' by my side in the kirk, and ridin' to the market on her ain Kelso naigie ? But I'll wager I'll be evens wi' the besom some day yet, or my name is no' Sandy Ewan !"

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: On a keen, snell-blowing February morning Sandy Ewan, Laird of the Boreland of Kirkanders, as well as of several surrounding farms, strode out across the short, spongy turf of the "ley" fields near the House of Boreland  to visit his sheep.

title: Strong Mac,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The girls, to whom ploughing matches were naught, had laughed specially at the discomfiture of Sandy Ewan, the son of the big farmer of the Boreland of Kirkanders, who rode over every morning on his own pony to be taught surveying and mensuration by the all-accomplished Dominie of Lowran.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Then the drive to Boreland once (George Welsh's, " Uncle George," youngest of the Penfillans) ; heart of winter, intense calm frost, and through Dumfries, at least 35 miles for poor "Larry" and us; very beautiful that too, and very strange, past the base of towering New Abbey, huge ruins, piercing grandly into the silent frosty sunset, on this hand, despicable cow-house of

title: The Black Douglas ... Second impression.
